title: Will India win the 2016 ICC World Twenty20 cricket tournament?
preds: You can close this question. India lost the semi-finals of the tournament. Answer : 0%
West Indies and England are through to the finals.
Wow, way to go, West Indies! Amazing.
India have lost their semi final to the West Indies
India is destroying West Indies right now and got to be a heavy favorite in the final.
Past India v/s WI results and past India v/s England results.
Raising p on England in the final
Considering India is playing at home, West Indies are  the underdog . India in the final seems like a safe bet. England vs. India in the final is a different story.
Upping slightly on England beating New Zealand

England just did India a huge favour by beating NZ in the first semi final. English batting line up has hit some impressive form with Roy, Root, Buttler all doing well in this tournament. I would now give 60% odds on India beating them in the final.  Odds for Indian victory in tournament: 0.7 * 0.6 = 0.42 But instead of the rational 42%, I am now going all in with 100%, since I have been lower than the consensus for most of the duration of this question. Considering the few days that are left, I will probably only just about get back to the median Brier value.
India qualifies for the semi finals where it faces West Indies, going by their past performance it appears India stands a very good chance of getting into the finals.
This is getting interesting. They still have to best NZ.

Through to the semi finals, which is knockout. Only NZ is undefeated, Bharat has 1 loss, and WI/ENG have 2 losses apiece. The Bookies give Bharat the best odds for winning. http://www.oddschecker.com.au/cricket/t20-world-cup

My own judgement based on watching the teams so far gave India a 27% chance, considering them just slightly more likely to win the semifinal on 31 March. West Indies lost to Afghanistan, the lowest ranked team while India miraculously survived against Bangladesh, the other qualifier, who had looked 99% certain of winning till they apparently lost their heads in the last three balls. http://www.oddschecker.com/cricket/t20-world-cup
However, the bookmakers have India 1/2 to beat West Indies, and 5/4 to win the tournament. Taking the two together, they imply a 67% chance to win the semi final and 68% to win the final (which I think is too optimistic). I'm therefore splitting the difference between my assessment and theirs.
India made it into semi-finals.  Proven their mettle.  Risk for all is that the Twenty20 format is always more dynamic and for the short duration of these games, about any team can win.
Well, they're one of the four teams, so leaving them at 16% seems unwarranted.
India is the favorite out of the 4 teams with a shot

I would put odds as follows India vs. Windies: 70% chance for India
NZ vs. Eng: 70% chance of victory for NZ If Final is against NZ: 50%
If Final is against England: 70% Overall odds for Indian victory = 0.7 * [0.7*0.5 + 0.3*0.7] = 0.7 * 0.56 = 39.2% --------------- As an aside, so far the only batsman doing well is Kohli (if one ignores Dhoni). This is not as strong a team as was thought at the start of the tournament when everyone in the team seemed to be doing well. If the team starts performing again (I am speaking mainly of the batsmen), India will take the tournament.  However, there is a real worry of a final against NZ considering that India has never beaten NZ in T20s. They have failed every single time in their 5 meetings!
I'm only able to follow the scores/commentary online, but that was a great comeback over Australia. I'm having way too much fun rooting for India, and will go all in with an unreasonable 100%

India are in the semi-finals after beating Australia in the last group match and are looking good enough to be favorites against the West Indies there. Any of the semi-finalists could win the tournament, though home advantage should count for India.

India need to win three matches. My estimation of their chance of beating:
Australia: 60%
West Indies: 70%
New Zealand/England: 70%
=.294

Allegation of potential match fixing.
http://www.ibnlive.com/cricketnext/news/world-t20-icc-should-investigate-india-bangladesh-match-says-former-pakistan-spinner-tauseef-1221542.html "his experience tells him that something was not right."
In order to win at this point, India would need to beat Australia, likely a 4-0 West Indies, and then perhaps a 5-0 New Zealand.  I don't favor the chances for a team that hasn't been batting well.
India had a somewhat difficult time with Pakistan. I will adjust after match 31 with Australia.

India has one more group match, which they must win to advance to the semi-finals i.e to win the tournament they have to win three in a row. Judging by performances so far, their chances of winning the last group match against Australia on Sunday are no  better than 60%. Their likely semi final opponents are the West Indies who have been playing well till now, so I'd say India's chances of beating them are 50% at best. If they get through to the finals, they could be up against New Zealand who beat them convincingly in their group match, so again 50% at best. Combining these three probabilities gives 15%, which will be my forecast till the result of Sunday's match.
Won against Bangladesh but only narrowly.
They need three straight wins against teams that seem to be very capable of beating them. Bangladesh game was uninspiring. Dropping to 12, handwaving a 50% chance of each victory from here on out.

After the match against Bangladesh, they now need 3 back to back victories against the strongest teams in the tournament (starting with Australia for deciding which of the two gets into Semis). Bangla win was not at all convincing but somewhat paradoxically, I think such a close win boosts the confidence level and they will perform better in the remaining games.  Odds: 60% against Aus, 55% in SF and 60% in Final.
Overall : 20%
looks like they are going into semi finals...

Mahendra Singh Dhoni hailed India as cricket's bounce  back kings after they again followed up an early defeat in a major tournament with an emphatic win and kick started their bid for World Twenty20 glory.
After their shock defeat on Tuesday to New Zealand in their first match, the hosts cruised to a six-wicket victory over arch rivals Pakistan in Kolkata late Saturday.
The defeat against New Zealand had put a question mark over India's status as red-hot favorites and triggered accusations of complacency.
But in a cauldron-like atmosphere of a packed Eden Gardens, Dhoni's men held their nerve and reached the target of 119 with 13 balls remaining. The bounce back from the humiliating 47-run reverse against the Kiwis came as no surprise to veteran skipper Dhoni who was captain when India won the inaugural World T20 in 2007 and the 2011 ODI World Cup after stuttering starts to their campaign.
India's prospects looked grim in 2011 after their first two matches against a traditional powerhouse included a tie with England followed by defeat to South Africa. India also got off to a slow start in 2007 when they tied with Pakistan before winning a bowl-out and then lost to New Zealand.
http://sports.yahoo.com/news/dhoni-lauds-india-crickets-turnaround-kings-051711707--spt.html;_ylt=AwrXgiI3wfJWkTIALoVNbK5_;_ylu=X3oDMTEyOWExdDM5BGNvbG8DZ3ExBHBvcwM0BHZ0aWQDQjAzMDNfMQRzZWMDc2M-
Dropping this a bunch as they essentially have to win their last 2 matches just to qualify for the semi's, one against Australia.  Then they have would still have to win the semi's and finals.
There are many teams with equal talent out there. A single good performance over a short period can swing a T20 match.
Home advantage but no good bowling attack. Too reliant on Kohli firing in the batting lineup
Adjusting upward after winning the match with Pakistan.

In a stunning upset, India have lost the opening match to New Zealand, who were ranked 5th by the bookmakers. India should still reach the semi-finals though now they'll need to win against second favorites Australia to do so. Reducing my probability accordingly.

I was way too confident on India before. Updating in response to NZ loss, since I had priced in a pretty high chance of them winning. India may have to win the rest of their group stage matches to proceed now, as only 2/5 teams go through. This includes probably beating Australia.
Based on an average of betting odds, the number of teams capable of winning and world T20 rankings.

Indian team's winning streak of 11 games ended in the warm up game against South Africa. Admittedly, it cannot be counted as a real loss since the two in-form batsmen retired at 16th over to give batting experience to those coming lower down in the order. But I think it is clear that when playing South Africa, chances of India winning is only 50% (they lost the home T20 series too to SA recently). Expecting SA to be facing India in the final, and consequently, I put the overall odds now at 30%.

Team is maintaining the winning momentum. Just won impressively against the Windies. Time to adjust my forecast.
Same logic as earlier, except I am now putting the odds of making SF at 80%, winning SF at 75% and winning F at 70%.
Overall at 42%.

The group stage is difficult as it allows only 2 teams to go through putting pressure on even the strong teams right at the start. 
I put the chance of qualifying for semis at 70%. Victory in SF at 65% and victory in Final at 60%. 
Taken together, I can't give better odds than about 27% at the start of tournament.

I got no clue why I am participating in this.
I am staying ~5% below the consensus. Whatever the consensus might be.
Get me out of here!
Increasing odds in line with betting markets (India is now 5/2 instead of 7/2)
Increasing after the win against Pakistan in the Asia Cup.
Perhaps we will all be more enlightened on this topic when play actually begins.  For now I'm sticking with something like 35% because why not.

Realistically there are eight teams who could possibly win under any circumstances. Nobody who isn't a test playing nation is going to, so the base rate for these should be 12.5%. On top of this, India have home advantage. The IPL means their players are the most experienced in the format. I don't especially trust the ICC rankings for T20 internationals, due to lack of matches between tournaments in this format, but India are ranked number one, and have plenty of players ranked near the top. Every bookmaker currently has India as favourites to win.  Holding me back from going further is the inherent unpredictability of T20 cricket compared to other formats. With only 4 matches in the first round, losing 2 could put you out, and India are definitely not invincible. As there are only two group, both are hard, and Australia, New Zealand and Pakistan are all decent teams who can beat India. They recently beat Australia comfortably away, and Sri Lanka at home, but last year lost to South Africa comprehensively, and even lost a match to Zimbabwe. India are favourites, but I don't think any team has a higher than 1/4 chance of winning at this point. In terms of other teams - England have been playing well in short form cricket, but really only compared to what went before, so have an alright shot. The Saffers have recovered a little bit over the last month after what looked like a collapse of their team, and beat India well in T20s recently. Australia are better at other formats. New Zealand have lost Mccullum. Pakistan will do something stupid. Windies are much better at T20 than anything else, but still a bit of a mess. Sri Lanka have been badly damaged by retirements. In order of likelihood  1. India 2. South Africa
3. England
4. Australia
5. New Zealand 6. Windies
7. Pakistan
8. Sri Lanka 9. Anyone else.
India has a very tough side.
Pretty much in line with the betting odds

India's loss to Australia in the One day series was a bit of a wake up call to their team. They have excellent batsmen, bowlers and their fielding has improved significantly in the last year but they didn't play well as a team. That aspect of the team performance has already seen improvement with their win over Australia in the first Twenty20 game in Adelaide.  With a home field advantage and masses of wildly enthusiastic fans, India have to be favourites

While India (#8 in current rankings) will get a boost from hosting the tournament, their group stage consists of three teams with a higher rating in T20, with only two teams advancing.  A tough semifinal match against (likely) another top 5 team would await.

Realistically there are 8 teams in with a shout. Let's say, since it's T20, given the short nature of the game, the base rate is 12.5%.  The bookies have them at around 7/2 as joint favourites with the Aussies. Let's call this around 33%. I don't think it's this high since I think the bookies are factoring in home advantage when historically it doesn't make much difference in short form cricket.  Plus they have just been demolished by the Aussies in one dayers. Trianglulating between these factors lands me at around 18%, but will add 4pp because 2 other contending teams are rapidly demising (SA and SL).
Although away - The Aussies won recent games decisively

Base rate of ~25%  based on current prediction markets and India's record in T20 world cups. However several factors which make suggest this forecast may be too optimistic:
- Current T20 and ODI rankings indicate probability of winning is much lower (although cricket rankings are imperfect)
- Host nation performance is typically underwhelming with host nation finishing on average 6th overall
- Qualitative factors are immense pressure and expectation on India team to deliver given popularity of cricket in India
- Although India has a decent team, many of the other competing countries have teams that are in very good form with recent top tier competition experience (ODI World Cup)
- Influence of Indian betting market on predication markets (local bias) There is some argument for home ground advantage but as others have mentioned, many of the world's top players now have substantial experience playing T20 in India.  Therefore adjusting forecast from base rate to 15%. Will review in light of upcoming Indian T20 matches.
Home court advantage and massive fan participation usually do the trick
Twenty 20 in India, India has a better track record

I don't know anything about cricket, but a team that isn't the consensus #1 in the world probably shouldn't be over 50% to win a 16-team tournament. One constant, in articles I've read about the T20, is that the type of cricket played in the tournament is "unpredictable", with a lot of room for randomness. This should lead to more evenness than we'd expect, given each team's respective strength, which further weakens India's chances. There seem to be three or four teams that are roughly on India's level, with another three or four teams that are reasonable contenders. My mental model looks something like 60% (one of the top four teams), 30% (one of the next four teams), 10% (one of the other eight teams). If we give India 1/4 the share of the top four, that's 15%. On the one hand, I could give bonus points for home field advantage; on the other hand, people who consider India one of the top teams (despite their 7th-place world ranking) already seem to be accounting for home-field advantage. I'll start off at 18% and watch carefully in March.
Good team but some better teams out there
Poor team comradaderie. Ageing team. Poor recent performance.

Baseline is 6.25% if all teams had even odds (16 teams in tournament). Current betting odds show India at 100/30 which are the best odds in the field - second best odds at 11/2 for Australia and England. I did a rough calculation of odds available by country - 11 countries were shown with odds. Also looked at past winners - India finished 2nd in the last competition - I looked at countries that finished 2nd and how they did the next competition - Sri Lanka won after finishing 2nd and so did Pakistan back in 2009. Host nations haven't produced a winner in the past, no strong indicator of team performance; might be some added pressure from hosting.
If Dhoni and Kohli come around, they have a chance
Home ground advantage, and Twenty20 is a batsmans game. india has a strong batting lineup.
India in home is pretty strong.
home ground; 'strong' spin attack in familiar locations
Did some research by checking the odds at various Sports Books (Ladbrokes 11/4, 36%, BetFair 7-2 28%) so I am going to raise my forecast to match the Bet Fair projection

Following current betting odds http://www.oddschecker.com/cricket/t20-world-cup/twenty20-world-cup/winner. India is the favorite at 7/2, same as last month. I'm giving them slightly better chances than the bookmakers do. This is an unpredictable format, and 8 out of the 10 teams could justifiably be given at least a 10% chance of winning.
Strong team and good team leadership
India will be in the top four ,and with a local crowd behind them their chances are above 25%.
India are ranked somewhere between 4th and 6th in the world, but hosting the tournament is worth something, although in 6 tourneys, only 1 host has made the final (lost).

There are four usual suspects (title contenders) in any ICC world cricket championship - Australia, India, South Africa and Sri Lanka. 
IPL has given the key players (if not all playing 11) of all these countries enough experience in Indian conditions. So to start with, the base rate probability of each one  winning the title should be 25%. I would not read much into recent T-20 results especially in bi-lateral matches. South Africa mostly does well in these low stake matches while India does  better in world cups. On top of that, India's home support  give definite edge to India. 
That said, T20 remains the most difficult version to call. T20 world cups have produced 5 different winners in previous 5 editions. On the other hand, 4 out the past 5 50-over world cup tournaments have been won by Australia. So we can not ascribe significantly high probability to any one nation.
Now to maths:
India can advance to next stage (semi-final) by either winning the group or coming second. 

I estimate that India has 36% probability of winning the group and 45% of coming second. I have just considered one path to the top - winning all its matches. Similarly, there is 45% probability that India loses just one of its four matches which will ensure at least a second spot in the group. 
I know there could be other permutations also but that would only increase the probability (apart from increasing the complexity to calculate the odds).  India's progression to Final and to the title will depend on who it faces in these rounds. I believe India's chances to win the semi-final is higher if it does not face South Africa. Similarly, the chances to win the Final are higher if the opposition is not Australia. Building all these scenarios in, I would put my probability at 29%.

Base rate is consensus: 25%. They are favourites with books (implied odds 7/2 - 11/4 22-26%).
ODI world cup: home winners are getting more common. (Australia and India recently). Indian pitches are distinctive. Countries seem to be getting worse at playing away. 
India have IPL so lots of experience. But lots of international players take part too.
The two factors above make me want to put the probability nearer 35%
Previous T20 world cups: India have won one of the five (the first in 2007 in SA). Came 2nd once in 2014. Sri Lanka have won once with two seconds. No team has won twice.
India ODI and T20 ranking: They are 2nd in the ODI rankings, but 8th(!!!) in the T20 rankings. This makes me want to lower the probability to below the base rate!
Recent T20 results: Lost 2-0 to SA at home. Drew 1-1 with Zim away.
They’ve only won one T20 series (a lone T20 in 2013/14 at home against Aus) going back to 2012. But long term form in T20 doesn’t really exist.
I think home advantage and conditions will prove vital. The Asian nations also have a warm up tournament. Some pundits are touting SA with their strong one day batting, but I think Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Australia and India are the best shouts. England and New Zealand probably don’t have the right talents for the conditions. 
Game theory makes me think I should stick my neck out and show some confidence in India, even though it’ll cost me if I’m wrong.
Take 5% of betting market as the weight of Indian optimism bias is probably distorting the market (c.f. England at World Cups)

The fact that there are only 7 or 8 teams that have any chance of winning gives us a base rate of 13% or so. India are currently slightly behind in the rankings but it is close and they were runners up in 2014. Seeing as the tournament is being hosted by India I have to raise their chances some what although Sri Lanka are probably overall favourites.
Significant other competitors make this an even competition

In an inherently unpredictable game, there are multiple other strong teams that can win the tournament.  With the best international players now taking part in the IPL the 'home-field' advantage is reduced and hence my 20% is reduced to a 15% as the West Indies, Australia, England, South Africa, Pakistan all field teams with players capable of grabbing any game.

Current betting odds are 9/2 so 22% but India has had such issues lately with sports and the added pressure of hosting I suspect means that they are even less likely to pull this one off.  Australia for the victory.
strong team at home.  all with IPL experience.  Good record in the competition. one of three favourites.
Using an average of betting market probabilities.
Home advantage doesn't seem to help. India's current ranking in ICC T20I shows them at number 7 and there are 16 teams in the tourney.

FORECAST #1:  2JAN16        **happy new year fellow forecasters**   - Starting of: India faces 9 coutries in the ICC World Twenty20 tournament in India 
- India is part of group 2, together with New Zealand, Pakistan and Australia. Two countries out of four from the group proceed to the semi-finals [1] .
- First, let's look at the wisdom of the bookies. They heavily favour India winning the 2016 ICC: 
 * a aggregate of 10 bookies gives India a 26% of winning, with a standard deviation of 2%   [3]
 * another aggregate of 28 bookies give India a 33% change of winning, with a standard deviation of 3%  [7] - Second, let's now examine the pathways towards a win. For this, India first has to come first or second in the group. 
 * India has 11 pathways to obtain 2 or more wins
 * The chance of India becoming #1 or #2 is approximated by taking the ODI outcomes of historical matches in India (so which have the home advantage, but are different to T20 matches) [2] [5] [6]:
 * India - Pakistan  30 matches :         11 wins, 19 lost      ( 51 wins, 72 lost overall)  
 * India - New Zealand  26 matches:  21 wins,  5 lost       (46 wins, 41 lost overall)
 * India - Australia  46 matches:          21 wins, 25 lost      (40 wins, 48 lost)
 * India against qualifier from Round A : this will be either Bangladesh, Netherlands, Ireland or Oman: 23%/24% = 93%  (using Bookies [3])
 * the statistics for the 11 pathways to reach the semi-finals gives a 91% chance  (for example pathway 1 = 11/30 * 21/26 * 25/46 * 5%)  - Third, for India to win the semi-final and final requires 2 wins which I compute using an aggregate of 9 Bookies [3]:
* India has a 3.8 'score', meaning 1-in-3.8 chance of winning, with the average score of the other 7 best contestants being 8.1, and best 3 other being 7.3). Winning the semi against the 7 best others and final agains the 4 best others gives: 26%/38% * 26%/40% = 45%
- Mathmatical chance of winning, is winning the first group times chance of winning semi-final and final: 93% * 45% = 42% FORECAST: finishing by averaging the two bookies and my own calculation gives: 42% + 26% + 33% / 3 = 34%

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/30/sports/cricket/pakistan-cricket-mired-in-threefold-controversy.html?emc=edit_ee_20151230&nl=todaysheadlines-europe&nlid=70183565&_r=0
But it was doping that dealt a hammer blow Sunday, with potential consequences through 2016 and beyond. Pakistan’s star spin bowler, Yasir Shah, tested positive for the banned diuretic chlorthalidone and has been suspended while he goes through the International Cricket Council’s disciplinary procedures. Shah, 29, has bowled so superbly in his first 12 five-day tests for Pakistan, taking 76 wickets, that he is already fourth in the world rankings. Saeed Ajmal, the world’s most dangerous spinner before his bowling action was ruled illegal, has scarcely been missed. Were Shah to be banned, Pakistan would miss him in three major events. First would be its own domestic Pakistan Super League, a Twenty20 tournament finally — after several years of planning and delays — scheduled to take place Feb. 4-23. While all five teams have the names of cities in Pakistan, the tournament will be played in the Emirates. But it at last gives Pakistan a stake in the developing global Twenty20 calendar, a particularly important development since its players are excluded from the lucrative Indian Premier League. The Super League will also give Pakistan’s top players valuable practice in the shortest cricket format before this year’s global championship — the World Twenty20 — which will be played in India between March 8 and April 3. Sri Lanka, the title holder and leader in the world rankings, will most likely start as favorite, but both India, as host, and Pakistan, which has an excellent World T20 record, are serious contenders. Happiest simply to be there will be Oman, making its first appearance.

India are clear favourites to win the world cup, due to a couple of reasons. Firstly, it's played in India, which (similar to other sub-continent wickets) is known for its' spinning pitches. India has several high quality spinners such as Ashwin, Jadeja etc., along with several part timers such as Raina, Kohli etc. who can spin the ball as well. In addition to the obvious home advantage, the Indian team is well balanced and has an ideal balance for a twenty 20, with aggressive batsmen, top notch fast bowlers and reliable spinners. The team that may threaten India for the title is South Africa (which clobbered India in an ODI series recently). However, others such as Sri Lanka and Pakistan may surprise as well. Barring the threat of South Africa, I expect a sub-continent team to lift the trophy.

The best odds you can get are 7/2 (a 22.22% chance of winning) and the worst 5/2 (28.6%) and the statistical 'mode' seems to be 3/1 (or 25%).  Fair odds ought to add up to 100%, but typically add up to 120-135% even ignoring the no-hopers.  So everyone's chances of winning are overstated by one fifth to one third.  As a rule of thumb, favourites attract more money and so the market is better in that the odds are closer to the realistic outcome.  Hence a 3/1 favourite might only have its chances of winning overstated by 20%, not 30+%.  With 3/1 being the mode and average price for India to win, I subtract 20% of that as 'premium' and give them a 20% actual chance.

The question needs to clarify whether it refers to the mens or womens tournament, as both are being  played simultaneously. If it's the women, then I'd give India no more than 5% at best, as England, Australia and New Zealand have much better chances. However, presuming we are being asked to forecast the men's tournament, the following factors have to be considered. 1. India are playing at home, in front of the world's largest and most partisan crowds. 
2. Against that, India are currently ranked #7 among international teams. http://www.icc-cricket.com/team-rankings/t20i
3. India lost its home series against South Africa just last month.
4. India is in a tough qualifying group, along with Australia, New Zealand, Pakistan and a qualifier. Only two teams can go forward.  Chance  of qualifying is probably less than 50% even with home advantage.
5. Oddschecker makes them 7/2, ahead of Australia (11/2) and South Africa (6/1). http://www.oddschecker.com/cricket/t20-world-cup/twenty20-world-cup/winner
6. Though no host country has won the World T20, there was a similar jinx in the 50 over world cup for more than 25 years, but the last two have been won by the home teams (India and Australia respectively).
7. Of the three forms of cricket, T20 is the least predictable.

They're good and home field advantage will help, but the field is too evenly matched (http://www.icc-cricket.com/team-rankings/t20i).  Getting out of Group 2 will be just as hard as the knockout rounds.

The public's passion for cricket in India is incredibly high, and there have been studies conducted regarding the beneficial effects of an enthusiastic crowd on the physiology and mental outlook of athletes when they are playing in their home town or country.

I'm not entirely clear on the format of the tournament, but it seems the teams play through two rounds before arriving at the knockout stage (the semi-finals). Out of the five previous world cup tournaments, India has made it to the semi-finals two times out of five: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ICC_World_Twenty20
Further down the page you can see that the host nation has never won the tournament at home (only making it to the knockout stage once). However, I think the sample size here is too small to make any meaningful conclusions. A better indication might be India's win percentage, which is the second highest after Sri Lanka across all the world cups. Because of this I'm assigning a high probability that India makes it to the knockout stage: 0.9 Once in the knockout stage, the competition will be tougher, so I'm going to assume even odds in both matches (semi-final and final). To win both: 0.5 * 0.5 = 0.25 Overall: 0.9 * 0.25 = ~0.23
